1.title: No More Status Quo, Rise Up, Be a Revolution: Part 1
1.plot: Pilot Episode, the Hosts begin introduction of the Revolution Evangelistic Association's new Television ministry, family, and themselves to a new audience expanding beyond their radio ministry into television. Referencing Friday night homeless assistance by feeding and giving blankets to those in need. Pastor Josh Jamison introduces his Wife on the set Melissa Jamison along with his associate pastor Tom Blauvelt.

2.title: No More Status Quo, Rise Up, Be a Revolution: Part 2
2.plot: Second part to the Pilot Episode, after the Hosts beginning Introductions of the Revolution Evangelistic association's new Television ministry the theme is set to encourage our generation to rise up and be a revolution , taking a stand for Christ. Josh Jamison tells the viewers no more status quo living. Christians need to rise up and come into an awakening to God as he is calling his people as a church to go higher and deeper by walking and doing the ministry. Associate Pastor Tom Blauvelt makes Reference to Ephesians 5:8 For you were once darkness, but now you are ...

3.title: Coming Alive to the Compelling Love of God: Part 1
3.plot: A compelling perspective on the nature of God and his love towards man and mans love towards God. Melissa Jamison discusses the love of God and if we as a people have not experienced the love of the father we need to allow God to love us. When we as a people come to God we begin to learn of a love that is fully functional and able to heal our emotional and spiritual wounds and broken heart where the Love of God will set you free.

4.title: Coming Alive to the Compelling Love of God: Part 2
4.plot: A conclusion to the topic of the nature of God and his love towards man and Man's love towards God. Pastor Josh Jamison states there is a measure of truth to Christians stating let the will of the Lord be done if when it's time for me to be free of something the lord will do it in me and I won't have to worry about it. He goes on to say the power of God is continuously available to us so we can rise up receive the revelation we need and come out of the bondage we may be in. He references Ephesians 4:22-24 Artwork of Christ embracing a child to his chest with love and ...

5.title: In God's Image: Part 1
5.plot: In part 1 of this 3 part discussion the hosts discuss that we need to see ourselves the way Christ sees us and how this is vital. Melissa Jamison makes reference to The Bible being a mirror for us as Christians it is a reflection of who we are in Christ. Pastor Jamison adds the biblical verse "Do not be conformed to the image of this world but be transformed by the renewing of your mind." The word of God is the source that we have to find out what our image is for what we are supposed to look like as a Christian.

6.title: In God's Image: Part 2
6.plot: Continuing into part two of the three part discussion the hosts discuss the need to ask of the lord for our daily spiritual and physical bread through prayer. We are created in the image of God and Pre-destined to do great things before him. The Hosts give encouragement to look to God as he is working in us and in our lives. The forgetful man looks into the mirror of God's word and forgets what he sees, but when he looks into the perfect law of liberty and does the work using the bible to find out what he looks like through God's eyes he realizes what he is created to...

9.title: Wilderness Outcry
9.plot: Focusing primarily on Prayer the hosts introduce the Wilderness Outcry event on June 14-18th sponsored primarily by Dutch Sheets Ministries crying out in the Wilderness for Christ. Encouraging viewers to pray about making a tent camping trip to Poplar Bluff, MO at Mount Moriah and join the hundred thousand people anticipated to be present at this event. It's time for our generation to see a move of God; the vision is about restoring the dreams of God to our generation. The 60's Event Woodstock are referenced in this episode as a comparable type of event that will take...

16.title: Healing Is the Children's Bread
16.plot: Tom Blauvelt points out in Psalm 2:1 why do the nations conspire and the peoples plot in vain? Speaking from God's perspective he looks at the government's and nation's leaders plotting to overthrow God and replace him with their vein religion and vein philosophies. Every knee will bow and every tongue will confess including these leaders. Melissa Jamison gives a story of her child Joshua who's eye is swelled up to the size of a plumb, being a timely matter when she and her husband planned on leaving the country for the missionary field. The eye incident occurred ...

imdb.plot outline: The Revolution aims to step outside the typical realm of the broadcast Christian genre. Its innovative style of discussion around a table in a peaceful, low lit, comfortable surrounding differs from the pulpit pastor preaching. The topics convey a much different, younger perspective into Christianity and evangelism. The youthful and upbeat personalities allow the hosts to talk to the viewers and not at them. The Revolution intends to fire up emotion in the hearts of its viewers with everyday modern family experiences and testimonies fueled by the Bible itself. The show's goal is to bring back to the Lord those in the age group's of late 30's and younger.
imdb.title: Revolution 618
plot: Everyday modern family experiences and testimonies fueled by the Bible itself.::Bryan Kreutz

The Revolution aims to step outside the typical realm of the broadcast Christian genre. Its innovative style of discussion around a table in a peaceful, low lit, comfortable surrounding differs from the pulpit pastor preaching. The topics convey a much different, younger perspective into Christianity and evangelism. The youthful and upbeat personalities allow the hosts to talk to the viewers and not at them. The Revolution intends to fire up emotion in the hearts of its viewers with everyday modern family experiences and testimonies fueled by the Bible itself. The show's goal is to bring back to the Lord those in the age group's of late 30's and younger.::Bryan Kreutz
